channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: J.W. Anderson and the Addictive Rush of Fashion
item.description: Suzy Menkes, the IHT’s fashion editor, talks to Jonathan (“J.W. Anderson”) Anderson at London Fashion Week about unisex styling, working with Donnatella Versace and the “addictive” rush of the industry today.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE

item.title: India Ink: When the Himalayas Poured
item.description: A survivor tells his tale of survival and death as floods in northern India took the lives of hundreds of pilgrims.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR
item.media:description: A man pleaded with a soldier to allow him to board an army helicopter on Friday as the death toll from monsoon flooding in mountainous northern India reached nearly 600.

item.title: The Lede: Brazil’s World Cup Winners Support Protests
item.description: Four former stars of Brazil’s national soccer team — Romário, Pelé, Ronaldo and Rivaldo — have expressed their support for the protest movement in recent days.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY and SERGIO PEÇANHA

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: D.E.A. Agent in Colombia Is Killed in Possible Attempt at Robbery
item.description: Colombian authorities said the American Drug Enforcement Administration agent, James Watson, 43, was stabbed four times.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egyptian President’s Supporters Rally
item.description: Huge crowds of Islamist demonstrators packed a Cairo traffic circle and several surrounding streets on Friday in a show of support for President Mohamed Morsi.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: West Bank Premier Urged to Stay
item.description: President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority asked his prime minister to reconsider his decision to step down after just two weeks in office.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Helicopter Crashes in Nicaragua With Senior Officers on Board
item.description: A helicopter carrying senior officers of Nicaragua’s air force, including its second highest-ranking member, Col. Manuel Antonio López García, crashed Thursday. All 10 people on board are presumed dead.
item.dc:creator: By KARLA ZABLUDOVSKY

item.title: Turkish Capital Heats Up as Protests Subside in Istanbul
item.description: The crisis in Turkey has shifted to Ankara, the seat of the government’s power and, to a great extent, the object of protesters’ rage.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: How Angry Is Brazil? Pelé Now Has Feet of Clay
item.description: As Brazilian protests grow, even soccer comes under fire after Edson Arantes do Nascimento, the soccer legend known as Pelé, told Brazilians to “forget the protests.”
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO and WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:description: Soccer spectators protested in Rio de Janeiro on Thursday.

item.title: Brazil Tries to Calm Protester Concerns, Rebuking Violence
item.description: With cities across the nation heaving in the biggest protests in decades, President Dilma Rousseff said she would try to address some grievances.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO and WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: In a Turnabout, Syria Rebels Get Libyan Weapons
item.description: Weapons formerly in Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s stockpile are making their way to antigovernment forces in Syria, courtesy of Qatar, which has strong ties with Libyan rebel groups.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By C. J. CHIVERS, ERIC SCHMITT and MARK MAZZETTI
item.media:description: Crates of recoilless rifle rounds in a rebel cache in Idlib, Syria, bear the triangle symbol of arms sent to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

item.title: Ex-Contractor Is Charged in Leaks on N.S.A. Surveillance
item.description: Edward J. Snowden, whose release of classified files has sparked a debate over the proper limits of government monitoring, was charged with violating the Espionage Act and theft of government property.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SHANE

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Brazil’s Vinegar Uprising
item.description: Humor is a powerful weapon in the march toward full democracy.
item.dc:creator: By VANESSA BARBARA

item.title: China’s Credit Squeeze Relaxes as Interest Rates Drop
item.description: Tight credit eased Friday, but financial markets remained under pressure as Beijing seemed to be tackling poor lending practices.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID BARBOZA
item.media:description: The People's Bank of China in Beijing. Markets settled somewhat on Friday after the overnight lending rate between banks dropped.

item.title: Convictions in Morocco Based on Coerced Confessions, Rights Group Says
item.description: In a report, Human Rights Watch accused Moroccan judges of convicting defendants based on confessions obtained through torture and of ignoring evidence like DNA tests.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By AIDA ALAMI

item.title: Much Discourse, but No Surprises, Likely for Kerry in India
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry will meet Sunday with India’s prime minister, whom he persuaded to pursue a civil nuclear agreement in 2008.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Flooding in Alberta Forces 75,000 to Evacuate
item.description: Two rivers spilled into five neighborhoods in Calgary, the center of Canada’s oil and gas industry, leading to the closing of the city’s downtown.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: China’s New President Sets Up a Potential Showdown, With Himself
item.description: President Xi Jinping has raised expectations of bold economic liberalization, but also of defending Communist Party rule, leaving even insiders unsure how far he will push change.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Police officers outside the People’s Bank of China, the country’s central bank, in Beijing. The bank eased up on a cash squeeze Friday, a day after interest and interbank lending rates soared.

item.title: North Korean Diplomat Blames United States for Tensions but Calls for Peace Talks
item.description: The North Korea ambassador called sanctions part of an American blackmail policy and urged the United States to accept its offer of direct talks.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE and JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: At a news conference at the United Nations on Friday, North Korea’s envoy, Sin Son-ho, left, told member states to ignore sanctions against his country.

item.title: As Hezbollah Fights in Syria, Life Changes in a Lebanese Border Town
item.description: Followers face new uncertainties and anxieties as Hezbollah fights a different kind of war, more intimate and ambiguous than the group’s founding conflict with Israel.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A boy held a flag during the funeral of the Hezbollah fighter Ahmed Awad on Tuesday.

item.title: Devices Given to Chinese Legal Advocate Had Tracking Spyware, N.Y.U. Says
item.description: Officials at New York University said that an iPhone and an iPad given to Chen Guangcheng were loaded with spyware meant to track him during his fellowship there.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:credit: Mark Makela for The New York Times
item.media:description: Several electronic devices that were given to Chen Guangcheng last year were loaded with spyware designed to track his family’s movements and their online activity.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Daredevil’s Latest Test: Remaking Japan’s Democracy
item.description: At the end of his career, Hidetoshi Masunaga, 70, is pouring his time and fortune into an effort to apply the principle of one person, one vote to Japan’s democracy.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.media:description: In 2001, Hidetoshi Masunaga's courtroom victories made him the highest-paid lawyer in Japan.

item.title: Putin Puts Pensions at Risk in $43 Billion Bid to Jolt Economy
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin announced a risky stimulus program, along with an amnesty plan for white-collar criminals intended to improve investor confidence.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: June 21
item.description: A prayer meeting in Jammu and Kashmir for the victims of floods that struck the north Indian state of Uttarakhand.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Students in Jammu city, Jammu and Kashmir, praying for the victims of floods in Uttarakhand, which have claimed hundreds of lives and left thousands stranded in different parts of the mountainous state.

item.title: Religious School Bombing Kills 14 in Pakistan
item.description: Three militants, including a suicide bomber, attacked a Shiite school in northwestern Pakistan on Friday, killing at least 14 people and wounding 28 others.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: Rescue workers inspected the scene of a suicide bomb blast targeting a Shiite school on Friday on the outskirts of Peshawar, Pakistan.
